This one really is from life experience.
It's really strategies and steps to one's, really, beginning of the next life.
I turned 50 a year ago, and, so, that's also a transition time for me.

So, it was very personally written because there are many people who are going through transitions whether that's after or before a marriage, whether that's the empty nest syndrome, your children are leaving or have gone, and there's so many people going through transitions.
I was going through one, certainly, from the 40s to the 50s, and what that meant.
And my best friend, Yolanda King, who was the eldest daughter of Dr. Martin Luther King, died right after my 50th birthday celebration.
So, I began to ask myself what is it that life is all about, and, for me, it's about mentoring and helping people get to their success.
So many people are told, you know, be successful, but very few people give you the how to's.
So, unless someone takes the time to mentor you and give you the simple strategies, and they are very simple.
And you take one day at a time, you take one step at a time, and you look at your life and you say, what is the step that I need to work on?
I can't overwhelm myself, and work on everything at every time, but I can work on one thing at a time, and take one day at a time.
Now, the New York Times calls you, Billy Graham and Oprah rolled into one.
Why do you believe, Suzan, that the complications of life can be addressed so easily by following your ten steps?
Well, first of all, life doesn't have to be as complicated as it is.
Life really is a series of journeys and a series of seasons.
And you have to know which season you're in, and be able to do the things that are appropriate and applicable to that particular season.
And so, you know, as Oprah, she's a talk show host.
She talks with everybody, she makes them feel at ease.
You know, she makes them feel comfortable at whatever their particular line of work is or genre is of writing.
She doesn't try to make them into something they're not.
That's what this book is about.
We're not trying to change you into something you're not.
It's about finding the real you and being able to accent that, accentuate it, accelerate it, and really say, world, here I am.
You haven't seen me.
I've been sitting on the sidelines, but now I'm ready to come to the forefront.
Life really doesn't have to be that difficult, but you have to wait for your timing.
Timing is important.
You have to have a strategy for your life, a plan for your life.
It doesn't just happen, but if you put these steps in the order that works for you, then life can be meaningful and wonderful.
And everyone has a purpose.
My thing is find what that thing is, and then go for it.
You know, it's interesting that you would mention those daughters because that leads directly to the next question that I had for you because those daughters appear in the chapter called Kiss Up.
Yes.
And you talk about how kissing up can catapult you in a society, but kissing up often has been seen as having a negative connotation, suggesting insincerity among other things.
What kind of kissing up is good, and what kind is bad?
Well, that's a great question.
First of all, there's a difference between kissing up and sucking up.
Sucking up is kind of like doing anything for anybody whether you have moral integrity or whatever.
Kissing up is being intentional about being nice to people.
It is making intention that this day, this year, I am going to put my best foot forward.
No matter what the attitude in the room is like, when I come, I bring a positive one.
And those persons who have befriended me, and those who I am ready to befriend, I'm going to be good about it.
And, so, in the world, they call it reinventing.
What I'm saying is you have to have intention.
And you have to be intentional about being nice.
As a pastor, as a leader, you know, there are some days at seven, at eight in the morning, I'm not feeling all that great.
That's my wake up time.
But I'm also a public figure, and, so, I have to rise to the occasion, and I have to have that smile.
And I have to make sure that I go forward because my job is to bring inspiration to other people.
So, I can't go in the room all sulky and looking sad.
I've got to put my A-game on.
And what I say to everybody who's ready to go to the next phase of their life, is you've got to put your A game on.
You've got to be ready with your smile, with your presentation, kissing up and saying, I'm going to be nice.
When I walk into the room, that's when the party starts.
You know, I don't care how dull it's been, but when I walk into the room, the atmosphere is going to change because I bring in me a spirit of joy, of thankfulness, and intention about being nice.
You know, Suzan, at the end of the book, you write that there are many other ups that people can use which aren't fully addressed in the main body of the book.
One of them caught my attention, and I wondered why it wasn't more prominently mentioned, and why this particular up doesn't have its own chapter.
Do you know what it is?
What it that?
Shut up.
Isn't that a key for improving one's quality of life?
